Headline: Jenna Ellis, former Trump lawyer, will cooperate in Arizona election fraud case.
Summary: Jenna Ellis reached a cooperation agreement with Arizona prosecutors on Monday. The agreement will result in dropping the charges against her in the so-called 'fake electors' case. Prosecutors are dropping the nine felony counts that Ellis had faced in exchange for her cooperation. Ellis must testify "completely and truthfully" whenever requested by the Attorney General's Office and be available for interviews. Ellis pleaded guilty in October to illegally conspiring to overturn Trump’s 2020 election loss in Georgia and has been cooperating with prosecutors in Arizona. Ellis was at the right hand of former Trump attorney Rudy Giuliani, helping spread false claims of election fraud in Arizona and six other states. She is barred from practicing law in Colorado for three years after her guilty plea in Georgia. Ellis is one of 18 defendants in the Arizona ‘fake voters’ case stemming from the 2020 election.

Headline: Tropical Storm Debby hits Florida with floods, threat of record rain in Georgia.
Summary: A 19-year-old man died Monday afternoon when a large tree fell onto a porch at a home in Moultrie, Georgia. The driver of a tractor trailer that broke off and dropped into a canal in Tampa, Florida, was found 40 feet below the surface. Nearly 200,000 customers remained without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday afternoon, down from a peak of more than 350,000 earlier in the day. A rare high risk, level 4 of 4, of flooding rainfall is in place Monday from northern Florida to far southern South Carolina.Tropical Storm Debby made landfall early on Monday as a Category 1 hurricane over the gulf coast of Florida. The storm is expected to bring torrential rains as it continues to move north into Georgia overnight, according to the National Hurricane Center. Up to 30 inches of rainfall was forecast to cause flash flooding in coastal Georgia and South Carolina, and into North Carolina. The cities of Savannah, Georgia, and Charleston, South Carolina could both be drenched with a month’s worth of rain in a single day. If the rains from Debby are as intense and widespread as implied in the strong agreement among forecast models, Debby is likely to cause damage in excess of $10 billion.

Headline: Pro-Israel interests pour millions into defeating a second ‘Squad’ member.
Summary: Rep. Cori Bush has missed 187 votes between January 2023 and June 2024, making her fifth among lawmakers with the most missed votes. Of the four members who missed more votes, two were being treated for cancer, one had a spouse who died suddenly and one was running for president. Bush was the first member of Congress to call for a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, nine days after Hamas’s Oct  7, 2023 attack on Israel. While Bush says her constituents resent having their tax money funding the bombing of civilians, Bell told Abbie in an interview that his opponent is “wrong” in her stance. Bell is backed by the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), a powerful pro-Israel group which has poured millions into the race. AIPAC has spent around $1 5 million on behalf of Bush in the primary cycle.

Headline: Bishop Richard Henning named new Archbishop of Boston, replacing Cardinal Sean O'Malley.
Summary: Bishop Richard Henning, 59, was chosen by Pope Francis to succeed Cardinal Sean O’Malley. Henning currently leads the Diocese of Providence in Rhode Island. He will be formally installed as archbishop at the Cathedral of the Holy Cross, the mother church of the Archdiocese of Boston, in the South End on Oct 31. The position could put Henning in line to become a cardinal, with voting power to elect the next pope. O'Malley is expected to stay on at the Pontifical Commission for the Protection of Minors for the time being at the personal request of Pope Francis. He said that his time will likely be divided between Boston and the Capuchin Monastery in Washington, D C. The Archbishop-elect expressed that he is “very grateful to Almighty God, for the abundance of life made possible by His love and His grace’

Headline: Rockets fired at Iraq's Ain al-Asad air base, which houses US forces.
Summary: U S defense officials said a rocket attack on Ain al-Asad air base in Iraq injured several personnel. Comes as tensions in the Middle East escalate amid the Israel-Hamas war. Concerns in the region are mounting following last week's killing of senior members of militant groups Hamas and Hezbollah. Iran and its proxy groups Hamas, Hezbollah and the Houthis have all made threats to seek revenge for the deaths of their allies and leaders in the past week. The Islamic Republic could attack Israel in the next 24 to 48 hours following a major attack by Hezbollah that left two IDF soldiers injured. Tel Aviv is preparing to "cut the head off the snake" of Tehran and its sprawling proxy network as they plan an imminent coordinated strike. President Joe Biden was scheduled to meet with his national security team on Monday looking to ease tensions between Israel and Iran.

Headline: RFK Jr. says he left a dead bear in Central Park as a joke.
Summary: Independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr posted a three-minute-long video Sunday night revealing he had left the dead bear in the park. Kennedy described the 2014 incident in a video that was posted to social media Sunday. He said it would be included in a New Yorker article that he expected to be damaging. Democrats have repeatedly accused Kennedy of running as a spoiler candidate in the election and on Monday jumped on the story to criticize him for his behavior. The article was published Monday and included a photo of Kennedy with his fingers in the bear's bloodied mouth. The image echoes a photo published by Vanity Fair last month of Kennedy pretending to eat a cooked animal carcass. The state agency that investigated the bizarre incident said the statute of limitations for the decade-old offense has long since expired. RFK Jr says he landed on the idea of leaving the bear cub’s carcass in Central Park next to an old bicycle he had in his vehicle as part of a ploy to make the cub's death look like an accident.

Headline: 13-year-old boy killed when a tree falls on home during Hurricane Debby.
Summary: A 13-year-old boy was killed Monday morning when a tree fell on his family’s mobile home in Levy County, Florida. The boy was the first known casualty of Hurricane Debby, though three other people have died in car accidents. The storm made landfall as a Category 1 storm near Steinhatchee, a tiny community in northern Florida of less than 1,000 residents. Nearly 300,000 customers were without power in Florida and Georgia on Monday. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has declared a state of emergency in 61 counties. Flooding is expected to be especially severe in low-lying areas near the coast. Vice President Kamala Harris postponed her campaign rally scheduled for Friday in Savannah, Georgia, because of the expected deluge there. The Pacific currently has four named storms spinning at the same time: Carlotta, Daniel, Emilia and Fabio.

Headline: Supreme Court rejects Missouri's long-shot bid to block Trump's gag order.
Summary: Supreme Court rejects Missouri's request to block Trump’s New York gag order, sentencing. New York Attorney General Letitia James says there is no basis for the Supreme Court to get involved. James says Missouri is "seeking to further the individual interests of former President Trump" Trump's sentencing was originally scheduled for July 11, but it has been postponed at least until September in the wake of a Supreme Court decision holding that former presidents have broad immunity from prosecution for their official acts. NEW: West Texas Intermediate crude futures climbed $1 18, or 1 6%, to $74 12 per barrel by 1022 GMT, or in early trade in Asia. U S personnel injured in attack against a military base in Iraq on Monday, three U S officials told Reuters. Concerns in the region mounted following last week”s killing of senior members of militant groups Hamas and Hezbollah. Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu faces anger in Israel and abroad over his handling of Gaza ceasefire talks.

Headline: Virginia man, Frank Carillo, threatened to kill Kamala Harris, authorities say.
Summary: Frank Lucio Carillo, of Winchester, Virginia, posted a series of violent threats about Harris last month using an alias on the conservative social media site GETTR. Investigators alleged that Carillo had posted 19 times about Harris, including threats to shoot, stab and burn her alive. Other federal officials who were targeted included President Joe Biden and FBI Director Christopher Wray, the complaint alleged. Investigators said a search of Carillo's home turned up two guns — a handgun that he purchased last year and an RF-15 rifle that he bought this year  He also allegedly had thousands of rounds of ammunition.Frank Lucio Carillo, 66, of Winchester, Virginia, is being temporarily detained pending a court hearing scheduled for Thursday. Investigators alleged that Carillo had posted 19 times about Harris, including threats to shoot, stab and burn her alive. Other federal officials who were targeted included President Joe Biden and FBI Director Christopher Wray, the complaint alleged. FBI recovered a pistol and an AR-15, which the affidavit said he had purchased in February. Carillo is charged under 18 U S  Code § 871 with “knowingly and willfully mak[ing] a threat to take the life of and to inflict bodily harm upon the Vice President of the United States”

Headline: Louisiana governor tells parents against the Ten Commandments in classrooms: 'Tell your child not to do so.''
Summary: Louisiana Gov. Jeff Landry has a suggestion for parents who don't believe the Ten Commandments should be displayed in public school classrooms. "Tell your child not to look at them," he told reporters Monday. A coalition of parents — Jewish, Christian, Unitarian Universalist and nonreligious — are suing the state. They argue that the legislation "substantially interferes with and burdens" their First Amendment right to raise their children with whatever religious doctrine they want. The U S  Supreme Court last weighed in on the issue of the Ten commandments in public schools in 1980, when the justices ruled 5-4 to strike down Kentucky's law.Louisiana is the only state to require that the Ten Commandments be displayed in the classrooms of all public schools and state-funded universities. A group of Louisiana parents and civil rights organizations have sued to stop the law. They argue a state requiring a religious text in all classrooms violates the establishment clause of the US Constitution. Louisiana's attorney general says the state will file a brief Monday, moving to dismiss the case on the grounds no one has been harmed because the law is not yet in effect. The deadline to comply, Jan  1, 2025, remains in place for schools across the state.

Headline: Special prosecutors plan to file criminal charges against the police chief who led the Marion raid.
Summary: Prosecutors plan to charge former Marion Police Chief Gideon Cody with a low-level felony. Cody led a raid last year on the Marion County Record and the homes of the newspaper publisher and councilwoman. Police didn’t commit any crimes by investigating baseless suspicion of identity theft or carrying out the raid, prosecutors say. The report also clears Marion County record reporter Phyllis Zorn and editor Eric Meyer of wrongdoing.“He was just a rabid squirrel in a cage and just off doing his own thing,” KBI agent in charge says of Cody.Expected charge for former Chief Gideon Cody stem from the raid of the Marion County Record in August of 2023. The anticipated charge appears centered on text mails, which appear to have been sent before the raid. A felony obstruction charge could be punished by up to nine months in prison for a first-time offender, though the typical sentence would be 18 months or less on probation. A misdemeanor charge c could be punishable by 18 months on probation or less, and a felony charge c is possible. The prosecutors have not yet filed the criminal case, as they are collaborating with the Colorado Bureau of Investigation.

Headline: EF-1 tornado hits downtown Buffalo, NWS confirms.
Summary: EF-1 tornado with an estimated peak wind of 90 mph touched down in Buffalo on Monday. The tornado traveled a 1 4-mile (2 25-kilometer) path, damaging buildings and sending debris swirling. It is the third tornado reported in Erie County in a month and the third confirmed tornado in the area in three weeks. New York has broken its record for the most confirmed tornadoes in one year, with 26 tornadoes. A video shared by Erie County on X showed the tornado come ashore from Lake Ontario at LaSaSa.The National Weather Service confirms an EF-1 tornado touched down in the city of Buffalo Monday afternoon. It was determined to begin at the shore near where Lake Erie flows into the Niagara River and traveled a 1 4-mile (2 25-kilometer) path. The tornado caused some minor damage to a tree and a few windows at Hutchinson Central Technical High School, PS 304. No injuries have been reported. It is the third tornado reported in Erie County in a month and the third confirmed in neighboring Genesee County the same day.
